content:
The Boss DS-1 is a classic distortion pedal that can add a lot of grit and character to your sound. The good news is that the Fender Mustang I V2 can work well with a distortion pedal like the DS-1, especially since it's a pedal-friendly amp.

The Mustang I V2 has a clean and relatively neutral tone, which makes it a great platform for pedals. The amp's clean channel can provide a solid foundation for your distorted sound, and the pedal can add the grit and character you're looking for.

That being said, keep in mind that the Mustang I V2 is a solid-state amp, and it may not respond to pedals in the same way a tube amp would. Solid-state amps can sometimes sound a bit more sterile or harsh when driven hard, which might affect the tone of your distortion pedal.

However, the Mustang I V2 is a well-designed amp that's intended to work well with pedals, and many players have reported great results using it with distortion pedals. If you're already comfortable with the tone you're getting from the DS-1, the Mustang I V2 could be a great match.

To get the most out of your distortion pedal with the Mustang I V2, try the following:

* Use the clean channel: The clean channel on the Mustang I V2 is where you'll get the most headroom for your distortion pedal. This will allow the pedal to do its thing and add the grit and character you're looking for.
* Adjust the gain: Experiment with the gain setting on the amp to find the sweet spot where the pedal is doing its thing, but the amp isn't getting too loud or harsh.
* EQ to taste: Use the tone controls on the amp and the pedal to dial in a tone that works for you. You may need to adjust the EQ to compensate for the tone of the pedal.

If you're still unsure, you could consider trying out the Mustang I V2 with your DS-1 pedal before committing to a purchase. Many music stores offer demo or trial periods, so take advantage of those to see if the amp and pedal combination works for you.

Ultimately, if you're happy with your current tone and just looking for an amp to pair with your pedal, the Mustang I V2 could be a great choice. But if you're looking for an amp that can deliver a more aggressive, high-gain tone on its own, you might want to explore other options.
